RESOURCES_BANNER_HEADING: Knowing the steps to apply for a rental can be confusing!
RESOURCES_BYLINE: Follow our guide to take you on the journey of applying for a property
RESOURCES_QUIZ_QUESTION: How much do you think the average weekly rent in Melbourne is?
RESOURCES_QUIZ_RIGHT_ANSWER_PARA: The average weekly rent in Melbourne is A$500.
RESOURCES_STEP_1_BRIGHT_YELLOW_BOX: Click here to check out our Renter's Rights page for more information on rental laws
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_1_STEP_1: Understand the typical rent costs of the area
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_1_STEP_2_PART_3: terms and other legal requirements to protect your rights as a tenant
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_1_STEP_2_TOOLTIP: A rental contract between you and a landlord.
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_2_STEP_1: Know that you know how much rent will be a week, start saving up!
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_2_STEP_2_PART_1: Be aware that it is standard practice when securing a rental to also pay for a
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_2_STEP_2_PART_3: and the first month's rent so save more than you think you will need
RESOURCES_STEP_1_PARA_2_STEP_2_TOOLTIP: A returnable sum that you pay when starting a lease to cover possible damage to the property.
RESOURCES_TAB_TITLE: MyRentalCompass | What you need to do
step_2_bright_yellow_box: Complete the questionnaire for our Find a Suburb to Live feature to determine the best suburb for you
step_2_para_1_point_1: Contact your university's student services, as they may have resources to help you find rental accommodation
step_2_para_1_point_3: Arrange temporary accommodation for your first few days or weeks, like a hostel, hotel, or AirBnB
step_2_para_2_point_1: Use our site to help you find out which suburbs best suit your needs
step_2_para_2_point_2: Now you can begin finding listed rental properties that match your preferences
step_2_para_2_point_3: Now you can begin finding listed rental properties that match your preferences
step_3_para_1_point_1: Congratulations you have a found a property that you like. Now it is time to inspect it to make sure it suits your needs, and is safe to live in
step_3_para_1_point_2: Some things to consider when inspecting a property include:
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_1: Assess the general condition of the property, including walls, floors, ceilings, and windows
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_2: Check the locks on doors and windows to ensure they work properly
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_3: Verify the presence of smoke detectors, fire extinguishers, and carbon monoxide detectors if required by law.
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_4: Inspect appliances such as the stove, refrigerator, dishwasher, and washer/dryer (if included).
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_5: Test lights, faucets, and electrical outlets to ensure they are functional.
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_6: Turn on faucets and showers to check water pressure and temperature.
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_7: Consider if there's enough room for your belongings. Pay attention to the noise level in the area, especially during the day and night.
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_8: Evaluate the proximity to public transportation options if needed.
step_3_para_1_point_2_item_9: Explore the neighborhood to assess proximity to essential services, grocery stores, and schools.
step_4_checklist_description: Follow the checklist to make sure that you have everything you need to make a rental application
step_4_item_10_point_1: Be prepared to pay any application fees required by the landlord or property management company.
step_4_item_10_point_2: Also be prepared to pay the security deposit and first monthâ€™s rent promptly if your application is approved
step_4_item_11_point_1: Fill out the rental application form provided by the landlord or property manager accurately and completely.
step_4_item_11_point_2: Note that any application form will include require much of the information that has been listed above
step_4_item_1_point_1: Full legal name that matches your other documents, and contact details, including phone number and email address.
step_4_item_2_point_1: A copy of your passport, driver's license, or other government-issued ID.
step_4_item_3_point_1: Pay slips, employment letter, or bank statements to demonstrate your ability to pay rent.
step_4_item_3_point_2: If you are not working whilst being a student, provide proof of financial support from a scholarship, sponsor, or family
step_4_item_3_point_3: Recent bank statements to verify your financial stability and ability to cover rent and expenses.
step_4_item_4_point_1: Provide proof of your visa or residency status.
step_4_item_4_title: Proof of Visa or Residency Status
step_4_item_5_point_1: Contact information for previous landlords or property managers.
step_4_item_5_point_2: Rental references or recommendation letters from previous landlords if available.
step_4_item_6_point_1: Personal references who can vouch for your character and reliability.
step_4_item_6_point_2: If you are working, also include contact information for your employer or proof of current employment, such as a job offer letter.
step_4_item_7_point_1: If your income or credit doesn't meet the landlord's requirements, provide information about a co-signer who can guarantee the lease.
step_4_item_8_point_1: Write a brief letter explaining why you are a suitable tenant and why you want to rent the property.
step_4_item_8_title: Cover Letter or Letter of Intent
step_4_item_9_point_1: Provide the contact information of someone who can be reached in case of emergencies, preferably someone local as well as from your home country.
